Black-footed Albatross: Seabird with contrasting black and white plumage
Equipped with a long, hooked bill for prey capture
Features long, narrow wings suited for gliding over the ocean
Has distinctly black feet, uncommon among seabirds
Possesses a striking white head and neck, providing a stark contrast to its dark body
Laysan Albatross: A predominantly white seabird with black wingtips
Notable for its long, hooked bill and webbed feet, designed for a life at sea
Boasts a wingspan extending up to 3.5 feet, enabling impressive gliding capabilities
Exhibits a graceful flight pattern over ocean waters
Has a sturdy body adapted to the challenges of oceanic life
Sooty Albatross: Features a deep, sooty gray plumage, blending into the ocean's hues
Equipped with a long, hooked bill, ideal for catching slippery prey
Has a distinctive white band around its neck, setting it apart from similar species
Employs long, narrow wings for efficient soaring across vast ocean distances
Adapted with webbed feet for navigating the marine environment
Groove-billed Ani: Boasts a unique groove-billed beak, distinct among bird species
Features a sleek black plumage with a notable white stripe above the eyes
Tail longer than average, aiding in agile flight maneuvers
Zygodactyl feet allow for gripping branches and surfaces with ease
Predominantly found in the southern regions of the United States and Mexico
Crested Auklet: Small, black and white seabird with a unique white crest on its head
Black bill sharply contrasts with its plumage, aiding in prey capture
Body adorned with white spots, providing camouflage among coastal rocks
Legs and feet are uniformly black, matching its dark plumage
Adapted to cold climates with a dense feather coat
Least Auklet: Tiny seabird with contrasting black head, back, and white belly
Features a black bill and distinct white ring around black eyes
White spots on black wings create a distinctive pattern for identification
Has black legs and feet, consistent with its overall color scheme
Suited for life in arctic and subarctic environments
Parakeet Auklet: Small, stocky seabird with a striking black and white contrast
Features bright orange feet, unusual in its genus
Adorned with a white face and black bill, adding to its unique appearance
Employs a short, black tail for maneuvering in tight coastal niches
Black back and wings with white underside for thermal regulation
Rhinoceros Auklet: Characterized by a large, bulbous bill, resembling that of a rhinoceros
Boasts a black or dark grey plumage, blending seamlessly with rocky coasts
A white face with a black stripe behind the eye adds to its distinctiveness
Short, stubby tail and webbed feet are well-adapted for marine life
Features a unique black stripe down the center of its back
Brewer Blackbird: Exhibits a glossy, jet-black plumage with striking yellow eyes
Equipped with a long, curved beak for foraging seeds and insects
Displays a long tail that aids in aerial display and maneuvering
Has long, black legs, allowing for efficient ground foraging
Features subtle white spots on wings, visible during flight
Red-winged Blackbird: Notable for its vivid red and yellow wing markings, contrasted against black body
Possesses a sleek, yellow beak, used for various feeding habits
Red eyes lend a fierce look, aiding in territorial disputes
Sturdy black legs support its foraging activities in diverse habitats
Well-adapted to marsh and wetland environments
Rusty Blackbird: Exhibits seasonal rusty-brown feather tips, distinguishing it from other blackbirds
Yellow eyes pierce through its darker plumage, creating a striking visual
Black bill and legs complement its overall dark appearance
Medium-sized, versatile for both ground and aerial foraging
Primarily found across North America, adapting to various habitats
Yellow-headed Blackbird: Showcases a bright yellow head and chest, creating a stark contrast with its black body
Long, black beak is efficient in extracting food from aquatic environments
Yellow eyes add to the bird's vibrant head coloring
Equipped with black legs and feet, suited for marshland navigation
Adapts well to wetland habitats, with a diet ranging from insects to seeds
Bobolink: Distinguished by its contrasting black and white plumage.
Features a striking white collar against a black underside.
Notable for its white-striped black wings and back.
Displays a distinctively long black tail.
Indigo Bunting: Vivid blue coloration covers its entire body.
Black wings and tail accentuate its blue plumage.
A compact, conical bill characteristic of seed eaters.
Males display intense blue during breeding season.
Females and juveniles are brown with faint wing bars.
Lazuli Bunting: Exhibits a bright blue head and back with rusty underparts.
Features a white wing bar on dark wings.
Distinctive appearance includes a two-toned bill.
Male plumage transitions from blue to orange on the breast.
Females and juveniles are muted in color, with a streaked breast.
Painted Bunting: Known for its kaleidoscopic plumage of blue, green, and red.
Juvenile males and females are mostly green.
Short, stout bill for seed consumption.
Bright plumage is most vibrant in adult males.
Cardinal: Males are vibrant red with a black mask around the face.
Females are pale brown with hints of red in wings and tail.
Features a distinctive crest on top of its head.
Strong, conical bill tailored for seed consumption.
Notably vocal, with a variety of songs and calls.
Spotted Catbird: Dense greenish plumage with conspicuous white spots.
Known for its melodic and complex vocalizations.
Features a short, stout bill for fruit consumption.
Exhibits a long, black tail utilized in territorial display.
Gray Catbird: Slate gray plumage with a black cap.
Notable for its long, melodious song that mimics other birds.
Exhibits a distinctive reddish patch beneath its tail.
Prefers thickets and edges of forests.
Feeds on insects and berries, often foraging on the ground.
Yellow-breasted Chat: Bright yellow breast contrasts with its olive-green back.
Notable for its large size among North American warblers.
Exhibits an extensive repertoire of vocalizations.
Favors thickets and brushy areas for habitat.
White spectacles frame its eyes, highlighting a black face mask.
Eastern Towhee: Displays striking black, white, and rufous plumage.
Feeds primarily on the ground, often seen scratching in leaf litter.
Males are predominantly black with white sides.
Females and juveniles are brown where males are black.
Chuck-will Widow: Largest in its family, featuring cryptic brown, black, and gray plumage.
Notable for its nightjar song, repeating 'Chuck-will's-widow'.
Primarily nocturnal, known for catching insects in flight.
Exhibits long wings and a wide, gaping mouth for feeding.
Nests on the ground, relying on camouflage to protect its clutch.
Brandt Cormorant: Dark plumage overall with an iridescent sheen in sunlight.
Distinguishing feature includes a bright blue throat patch during breeding season.
Utilizes wings to 'fly' underwater while hunting fish.
Nests in large, dense colonies on cliffs or islands.
Long, hooked bill effective for catching and holding slippery prey.
Red-faced Cormorant: Dark plumage contrasts with striking red facial skin.
Prefers cold, northern waters, often seen diving from the surface.
Long neck and body streamline for underwater pursuit.
Breeds on steep, rocky cliffs near the ocean.
Feathers not fully waterproof, seen spreading wings to dry.
Pelagic Cormorant: Smallest of the cormorants, with glossy black plumage.
Breeding adults display white flank patches and a red face.
Highly adapted for marine life, feeds on fish and invertebrates.
Nests on sheer cliff faces overhanging water.
Flight is low over the water with rapid wing beats.
Bronzed Cowbird: Displays a bronzed iridescence on black plumage.
Eyes strikingly red in males, brown in females.
Known for its parasitic breeding, laying eggs in the nests of other species.
Exhibits a puffing and feather ruffling courtship display.
Prefers open or semi-open habitats, often seen near livestock.
Shiny Cowbird: Inclined to brood parasitism, impacting populations of host species.
Often found in flocks in open or lightly wooded areas.
Males perform a distinctive bowing display during courtship.
Females duller, with a more uniform brown coloration.
Brown Creeper: Camouflaged, brown streaked appearance with a white underside.
Spirals upward around tree trunks in search of insects.
Utilizes stiff tail feathers as a prop while climbing.
Nests behind loose bark on dead or dying trees.
Short, curved bill specialized for extracting insects from bark crevices.
American Crow: Entirely black with a strong bill and muscular legs.
Highly intelligent, known for problem-solving abilities.
Omnivorous diet includes invertebrates, seeds, and waste.
Complex social structure, often seen in large flocks.
Vocal bird, producing a variety of sounds beyond the typical 'caw'.
Fish Crow: Slightly smaller than the American Crow, with a more slender bill
Glossy black feathers, with a hoarser, nasal call
Coastal bird, feeds on fish and crustaceans as well as garbage
More buoyant flight than American Crow
Breeds in trees near water, often in small colonies
Black-billed Cuckoo: Slim, long-tailed bird with brownish-gray upperparts
White underparts with thin, black bill
Eats large quantities of caterpillars and insects
Secretive, more often heard than seen
Mangrove Cuckoo: Yellow-bellied with a gray face and brown upperparts
Inhabits mangroves and dense woodlands, elusive
Feeds on insects and small vertebrates
Low, guttural call notes, often in series
Nesting habits poorly understood due to secretive nature
Yellow-billed Cuckoo: Long, slender bird with brown back, white belly, and yellow bill
Eats insects, particularly fond of caterpillars
Nests in dense thickets and trees
Known for its ability to eat spiny caterpillars
Gray-crowned-Rosy Finch: Pink body, gray crown, and black back make it distinctive
Prefers alpine and tundra zones, often seen in flocks
Ground-foraging bird, eats seeds and insects
Bulky nest often placed on ground or low in bushes
High elevation dweller, hardy against cold temperatures
Purple Finch: Males raspberry red on head and breast, females streaky brown
Conical bill for seed and fruit eating
Song is a rich, warbling cascade of notes
Breeds in coniferous and mixed forests
Highly sociable outside of breeding season, often at feeders
Northern Flicker: Brown with black bars, distinctive red nape patch
Feeds on ground, mainly ants and beetles
Undulating flight with flashes of white rump patch
Drums on metal objects during courtship and to mark territory
Nests in tree cavities, often excavated by the bird itself
Acadian Flycatcher: Olive green upperparts, white underparts, and pale eye-ring
Inhabits dense forests and woodlands, near streams
Catches insects in mid-air with agile, fluttering flight
Nests are shallow cups of grass and spiderwebs
Great-Crested Flycatcher: Bright yellow belly, brown back, and long, rusty tail
Eats insects and fruits, catches insects in flight
Nests in tree cavities, may use snake skin in nest lining
Conspicuous crest and aggressive behavior towards intruders
Least Flycatcher: Grayish-olive upperparts, white underparts, and distinct eye-ring
Forages from a perch, short flights to snap up insects
Breeds in open woodlands and edges
Song is a sharp 'chebek', often repeated
Olive-sided Flycatcher: Dark olive-brown sides, white center, and throat
Perches at top of tall trees, distinctive 'quick, three beers!' call
Hunts flying insects from high perches, sallies out for prey
Frequents forest edges, clearings, and burned-over lands
Long-distance migrant, winters in South America
Scissor-tailed Flycatcher: Pale gray body, strikingly long, forked tail, and salmon-pink flanks
Insectivorous, hunts in graceful aerial sallies
Open country and roadside percher, often on wires
Nests in trees or shrubs, nest of sticks and grass
Winter in Central and South America, iconic of the Texas landscape
Vermilion Flycatcher: Brilliant red in males, females paler with white belly
Small, stocky, with a stout, black bill
Catches insects in midair with sally flights
Prefers open woodlands, scrub, and desert edges
Distinctive song is a series of sweet, clear phrases
Yellow-bellied Flycatcher: Bright yellow belly, olive-green upperparts, and white eye-ring
Insect eater, forages in dense foliage
Breeds in wet, northern forests, often near water
Frigatebird: Magnificent fliers, large wings, forked tail, males display red throat pouch
Soars high over oceans, rarely flaps wings
Feeds on fish and squid by snatching them from the ocean surface or theft from other birds
Nests in colonies on isolated islands
Known as the 'pirate bird' for its kleptoparasitic behavior
Northern Fulmar: Glides on stiff wings, petrel family, gray and white variations
Feeds on squid, fish, and krill by surface seizing or shallow diving
Breeds in dense colonies on cliffs, lays single white egg
Produces stomach oil as defense against predators
Flight pattern reminiscent of a stiff-winged albatross
Gadwall: Drabber than other ducks, males have a neat black rear end
Feeds by dabbling not diving, in shallow waters
Subtle plumage with intricate patterning upon closer inspection
Forms large, mixed-species flocks on wetlands and ponds
Nest is a shallow depression on the ground, well-hidden
American Goldfinch: Males bright yellow with black forehead in summer
Females and winter males more muted yellow-brown
Specialized bill for extracting seeds, notably from thistles and sunflowers
Breeds late in season, nests woven tightly and placed in shrubs
European Goldfinch: Vibrant red face, black and white head, brown body with yellow wing bars
Adaptable, found in gardens, parks, and wild landscapes
Feeds on thistle, teasel, and dandelion seeds
Distinctive liquid twittering song and call
Nests are compact and neat, with a foundation of twigs lined with wool and hair
Boat-tailed Grackle: Large, iridescent black birds with long legs and a distinctive keel-shaped tail
Males substantially larger than females, with a more pronounced tail
Favors salt marshes, coastal areas, but often found in city parks and suburban areas
Omnivorous, eating insects, grain, small vertebrates, and food waste
Males display with loud, jarring calls and glossy plumage to attract females
Eared Grebe: In breeding plumage, shows striking black neck and flanks, with a golden fan of feathers behind the eyes
Dense, compact body with a thin neck and sharply pointed bill
Aquatic, excellent diver, feeds on aquatic insects and fish
Builds floating nests anchored to submerged vegetation
Performs elaborate mating dances and displays
Horned Grebe: Breeding adults have black heads with conspicuous golden-yellow feather tufts
Small and compact, with a steep forehead and a short, pointed bill
Predominantly aquatic, feeds on small fish and aquatic invertebrates
Nests are floating platforms hidden in reeds
Known for its loud, trilling songs and aggressive territorial behavior
Pied-billed Grebe: Small, brownish water bird with a distinctive thick, white bill ring in breeding season
Expert diver, vanishes quickly at slightest alarm
Feeds on aquatic insects, fish, and amphibians
Builds a floating nest made of vegetation
Often heard before seen, emitting a peculiar, whinnying call
Western Grebe: Large, elegant with a long, swan-like neck and striking black-and-white plumage
Famed for its elaborate courtship dance, including synchronized water running
Feeds primarily on fish, captured with diving
Nests in dense colonies on large lakes, building floating nests of vegetation
In winter, migrates to coastal waters, becomes more solitary
Blue Grosbeak: Males are vibrant blue with rusty wing bars; females are cinnamon-brown
Inhabits shrubby areas and open woodlands, often near water
Feeds on insects and seeds, foraging on the ground and in vegetation
Song is a rich, melodious warble
Nests in dense vegetation, often low in trees or bushes
Evening Grosbeak: Large, stocky finch with a robust, conical bill
Males are bright yellow and black with a prominent white wing patch; females are more subdued
Frequents sunflower feeders in winter, often in large, noisy flocks
Feeds on tree seeds, especially in winter, and insects during breeding season
Breeds in coniferous forests, nest is a bulky platform of twigs
Pine Grosbeak: Large, chunky finch with rounded head and thick bill
Males are pink-red and gray; females and immatures are more gray with a yellow wash
Favors coniferous forests, feeds on seeds, buds, and berries
Gentle, mellow call, often forming loose flocks outside of breeding season
Nests high in trees, often returning to the same areas each year
Rose-breasted Grosbeak: Males have a striking black and white plumage with a rose-red breast patch; females are brown and streaked
Forages in trees and bushes for insects, seeds, and fruit
Song is a series of sweet whistles, similar to a robin's but more melodious
Breeds in deciduous forests, often near edges or clearings
Nests are a shallow cup in a tree or large shrub
Pigeon Guillemot: Black overall with distinctive white wing patches and bright red feet
Dives for fish and invertebrates, uses wings to 'fly' underwater
Nests in crevices and burrows on rocky coastlines
In flight, displays rapid wingbeats with white wing patch flashing
Calls are high-pitched and squeaky, often while in flight
California Gull: Medium-sized gull with a white body, gray back, and black wingtips with white spots
Yellow legs and a yellow bill with a black ring near the tip
Versatile feeder: eats insects, fish, eggs, and garbage
Nests in large colonies on the ground near water
Known for their loud, laughing call
Glaucous-winged Gull: Wings shaded with a unique glacier-blue hue
Bright yellow beak with a subtle red dot on the lower part
Legs and feet of a vivid yellow
Characteristic heavy build with a robust head
Heermann Gull: Distinctive red eyes encircled by a pale ring
Legs and webbed feet of a deep reddish hue
White tipped black tail visible in flight
Herring Gull: Classic seagull appearance with a white and grey palette
Yellow eyes with a fierce gaze
Powerful yellow beak accented with a red spot
Pinkish legs supporting its large body
Ivory Gull: Pure snowy plumage, an Arctic beauty
Black legs and bill, stark against its white feathers
Eyes like drops of golden honey
Small, dainty stature with a plump body
Wings tipped with a whisper of black
Ring-billed Gull: Clean white body with a graceful gray back
Prominent black band wrapping the yellow bill
Legs of a delicate lemony yellow
Eyes of a deep, enchanting red
Black wingtips adorned with white spots
Slaty-backed Gull: Robust body with a thickset neck
Back and wings painted in a dusky shade of slate gray
Striking yellow eyes set against a white head
Hefty bill marked with red, mounted on a fierce face
Legs and feet dipped in yellow, contrasting with its dark plumage
Western Gull: Large size with a white head and underparts
Back and wings cloaked in deep slate
Strong, hooked bill tinged with a hint of red
Pinkish-white legs giving a sturdy stance
Eyes of a pale, ghostly yellow
Anna Hummingbird: Brilliant emerald and ruby plumage shimmering in sunlight
Tiny frame capable of agile mid-air maneuvers
Straight, slender beak perfect for sipping nectar
Vibrant green feathers covering the body, with a dazzling ruby throat
Iridescent feathers casting a metallic sheen
Ruby-throated Hummingbird: Vibrant green upperparts with a ruby-red throat
Iridescent feathers that glimmer in direct sunlight
Tiny, agile body capable of hovering mid-air
Wings beat so fast they're often just a blur
Feeds on nectar from tubular flowers using its long, narrow beak
Rufous Hummingbird: Bright rufous (reddish-orange) feathers covering most of the body
Remarkably aggressive demeanor towards other hummingbirds
Long migration route stretching from Alaska to Mexico
Small size but capable of incredible aerial maneuvers
Prefers open areas, yards, and parks with plenty of flowers
Green Violetear: Vibrant green plumage with violet ear patches
Medium-sized hummingbird with a robust body
Distinctive, metallic buzzing song emitted during flight
Utilizes rapid wing flaps to hover in place while feeding
Favors highland forests, often found above the canopy level
Long-tailed Jaeger: Streamlined body with exceptionally long central tail feathers
Plumage varies from light gray to brown with white underparts
Adept flyer, often seen gliding low over ocean waves
Piratical behavior, known for aggressively chasing other birds for food
Breeds in Arctic tundra, winters at sea far from land
Pomarine Jaeger: Heavy, powerful build with broad wings and stout body
Large, hooked bill used for scavenging and attacking prey
Tail feathers twisted into a characteristic 'spoon' shape
Dark cap contrasting with lighter nape and underparts
Rarely seen inland, prefers life over open ocean waters
Blue Jay: Bright blue upperparts with white underparts and black banding
Loud, jarring calls often used to communicate with others
Intelligent, known for mimicking the calls of hawks
Crest on head can be raised or lowered depending on mood
Feeds on nuts, seeds, and occasionally small invertebrates
Florida Jay: Small, compact body with bright blue and white plumage
Endemic to Florida, particularly the scrub and oak thickets
Very territorial, stays near its birthplace its entire life
Lacks black markings on the head and wings, unlike other jays
Feeds on acorns, insects, and berries
Green Jay: Vibrant green body with blue head, wings, and tail
Prominent black face mask with a white stripe above
Loud and social, often found in noisy family groups
Uses sticks to extract insects from bark, showcasing tool use
Inhabits dense thickets and woodlands from Texas to Honduras
Dark-eyed Junco: Slate-gray or brown, depending on region, with a white belly
Known for the 'flash' of white tail feathers in flight
Ground feeder, often seen hopping on the forest floor
Prefers coniferous woods but adapts to various habitats
Distinctive trilling song and musical chirping calls
Tropical Kingbird: Bright yellow belly with a light gray head and darker wings
Aggressive defender of its territory, even against much larger birds
Long, forked tail often seen in a characteristic twitching motion
Feeds on flying insects which it catches in mid-air acrobatics
Favors open and semi-open areas across Central and South America
Gray Kingbird: Uniformly gray upperparts with a contrasting white underbelly
Notable for its large head and a heavy, straight bill
Often perches conspicuously, ready to sally forth after flying insects
Breeds in coastal areas, mangrove swamps, and islands
Distinctive, repetitive call sounds like a high-pitched, electronic buzz
Belted Kingfisher: Striking blue-gray plumage with a white collar and underparts
Large, crested head with a stout, dagger-like bill
Distinctive rattling call heard along rivers and lakeshores
Excels in diving to catch fish, its primary food
Nests in burrows along earthen banks
Green Kingfisher: Small, vibrant green above with white underparts
Prefers clean rivers and streams where it hunts fish from perches
Direct and fast flight often low over water
Male has a broad chestnut breast band which the female lacks
Usually solitary, defends feeding territories fiercely
Pied Kingfisher: Black and white plumage with a crest and unique hovering flight
One of the few kingfishers known to be capable of true hovering
Feeds predominantly on fish, diving headfirst into water to catch prey
Widely distributed across Africa and Asia near water bodies
Both sexes share distinctive double breast bands
Ringed Kingfisher: Large, robust body with blue-gray upperparts and orange-buff underparts
Prominent, shaggy crest and powerful bill
Loud, laughing call echoes along rivers and lakes
Often seen perched conspicuously along water bodies
Feeds mainly on fish, captured with dramatic plunging dives
White-breasted Kingfisher: Bright blue back and wings with a contrasting white front
Large head with a stout, reddish bill ideal for hunting fish and insects
Vocal and conspicuous; known for its loud, descending calls
Adaptable, found near water as well as in gardens and farmlands
Frequently perches on wires or bare branches over water
Red-legged Kittiwake: Small gull with a white body, gray back, and distinctive red legs
Black wingtips and a short, yellow bill
Breeds on steep, coastal cliffs in the Northern Pacific
Feeds primarily on fish and squid, often foraging at night
Usually silent at sea, but noisy at breeding colonies
Horned Lark: Small, ground-dwelling bird with brown back and yellow throat and face
Notable for the small black 'horns' of feathers on its head
Inhabits open fields and deserts where it forages for seeds and insects
Performs elaborate song flights during breeding season
Distinctive bright yellow face contrasts with its brown and black body markings
Pacific Loon: Striking breeding plumage with a black head, white stripes on neck, and checkered back
Notable for its eerie, wailing calls that echo across northern lakes
Powerful swimmer, dives to catch fish and invertebrates
Prefers cold northern waters for breeding, winters along coasts
Often seen in pairs or small groups, less social than other loons
Mallard: Familiar duck with iridescent green head and yellow bill in males
Females sport mottled brown camouflage to hide from predators
Effortless flyer, can migrate long distances seasonally
Omnivorous, feeds on aquatic vegetation, invertebrates, and grains
Adaptable to various habitats, often found in urban and suburban ponds
Western Meadowlark: Bright yellow throat and belly with a distinctive black 'V' on chest
Melodious flute-like song resonates through grasslands
Insects and seeds comprise its diet
Nests on the ground in a woven grass cup
Prefers open fields and meadows as habitats
Hooded Merganser: Small, strikingly patterned duck with a fan-shaped crest
Males have a black and white head and chestnut flanks
Excellent diver, uses serrated bill to catch fish and crustaceans
Nests in tree cavities near water bodies
Shy and elusive, often found in small flocks
Red-breasted Merganser: Streamlined body with a distinctive shaggy crest on the head
Males with striking red-brown breast and greenish head
Fast flyer, often seen flying low over water
Dives to catch fish, which form the bulk of its diet
Prefers coastal waters and large lakes, less commonly found on rivers
Mockingbird: Gray with a long tail and white wing patches visible in flight
Famous for mimicking songs and calls of other bird species
Territorial and fearless, often seen chasing away larger birds
Inhabits open areas with sparse vegetation, from suburbs to countryside
Mostly feeds on insects, berries, and seeds
Nighthawk: Camouflaged plumage blends with its nocturnal habitat
Renowned for its silent, swift flight during twilight
Catches flying insects in mid-air with its wide, gaping mouth
Nests on the ground or flat roofs without any material
Distinctive 'boom' sound made by males during courtship dives
Clark Nutcracker: Gray and black bird with a sharp, pointed bill
Famed for burying pine nuts in the ground as a winter food source
Resides in pine forests in mountainous regions
Strong flier, capable of covering long distances
Loud, harsh calls are a common sound in its habitat
White-breasted Nuthatch: Slate blue-gray back with a stark white underpart
Nimble climber, often seen upside down on tree trunks
Uses its long, slender bill to extract insects from bark crevices
Frequent visitor to bird feeders, attracted to seeds and nuts
Distinctive nasal calls often betray its presence in forests and woodlands
Baltimore Oriole: Vivid orange and black plumage, a striking contrast against green foliage
Weaves a hanging basket-like nest at the end of tree branches
Feeds on fruit, nectar, and insects, aiding in flower pollination
Migratory bird, winters in Central America
Melodious song and chattering calls are a welcome sign of spring
Hooded Oriole: Brilliant orange body with a contrasting black 'hood'
Prefers palm trees for nesting, using fibers to create hanging nests
Consumes nectar, insects, and fruits, often visiting feeders
Not shy around humans, frequently found in suburban gardens
Males perform elaborate courtship displays with fluffed feathers and bowed postures
Orchard Oriole: Rusty-orange and black coloring, smaller than many other orioles
Builds a tightly woven, cup-shaped nest in trees
Prefers open woodlands, orchards, and gardens as habitats
Feeds primarily on insects during breeding season for protein
Song is a series of clear, whistled notes and chatters
Scott Oriole: Males have a lemon-yellow body contrasting with a black hood and back
Inclined to arid landscapes with yucca plants, which are used for nesting
Both sexes exhibit a pointed bill suited for nectar feeding
Distinctive, melodious song can carry for long distances
Migrates to Mexico and Central America during the winter
Ovenbird: Dull olive-brown above with a strikingly spotted chest to mimic the forest floor
Named for its dome-shaped, ground nest which resembles an old-fashioned oven
Loud, teacher-teacher-teacher song is a hallmark of eastern forests
Forages on the ground for insects and spiders
Can be difficult to spot, but often betrays its presence with its song
Brown Pelican: Large bird with distinctive pouch under bill for catching fish
Plunges headfirst into water in spectacular fishing dives
Coastal dweller, rarely seen far from shore
Breeds in colonies on islands and coastal cliffs
Brown and gray plumage with a lighter neck and head
White Pelican: Immense wingspan and large white body with black flight feathers
Feeds cooperatively, herding fish before scooping them up
Inland lakes and marshes are preferred during breeding season
Performs impressively synchronized flight patterns with flock
Does not dive for fish, unlike the Brown Pelican
Western-Wood Pewee: Small, drab flycatcher with a faint vest and white underbelly
Feeds almost exclusively on flying insects, catching them in mid-flight
Sings a high-pitched, descending pee-a-wee call from treetops
Migrates to Central and South America for the winter
Sayornis: Small size with dusky plumage, often perching conspicuously
Frequent tail flicking when perched is characteristic
Insectivorous, using acrobatic flights to catch prey
Found near water, such as rivers and lakes, across the Americas
Simple, repetitive call notes often given in series
American Pipit: Slim, ground-dwelling bird with a streaked back and buffy sides
Inhabits open country from tundra to beaches
Constantly bobs its tail while walking on the ground
Feeds on insects and seeds, often in flocks during winter
Flight call is a sharp 'pipit,' from which its name derives
Whip-poor Will: Camouflage plumage blends perfectly with leaf litter on the forest floor
Nocturnal, feeds on flying insects at dusk and dawn
Named for its continuous, haunting whip-poor-will call at night
Rarely seen, more often heard during spring and summer nights
Nests on the ground without any nest structure
Horned Puffin: Distinctive large orange bill and white face with a black back
Breeds on rocky cliff sides in the Northern Pacific
Swims underwater using wings to 'fly' and catch fish
Social, often found in large colonies on remote islands
In winter, lives far out to sea, rarely seen near land
Common Raven: Large, all-black bird with a thick neck and shaggy throat feathers
Known for its intelligence and problem-solving abilities
Variety of vocalizations from deep croaks to complex mimicry
Adaptable, inhabits diverse environments from wilderness to urban areas
Feeds on a wide range of items, from carrion to small animals and fruit
White-necked Raven: Slightly smaller than the common raven with a white patch on the back of the neck
Lives in East Africa, from open fields to mountains
Highly opportunistic eater, including fruit, insects, and carrion
Social behavior includes playful aerial acrobatics
American Redstart: Small, active warbler with striking orange patches on wings and tail
Males are black with bright patches, while females are gray with yellow patches
Flicks its tail frequently to flush out insect prey
Prefers deciduous forests with dense understory
Song is a series of high-pitched, sweet notes
Geococcyx: Known as the roadrunner, famous for its fast, ground-based running
Long-legged with a crest and a long, trailing tail used for steering
Eats a variety of prey, including insects, lizards, and small mammals
Distinctive 'coo-coo-coo' call, often in a descending series
Inhabits deserts and scrublands of the Southwestern United States
Loggerhead Shrike: Small, predatory songbird with a black mask and gray body
Impales its prey on thorns or barbed wire for storage
Breeds in open habitats including farmland and grasslands
Sharp, hooked bill for attacking and consuming prey
Song is a series of harsh, jarring notes interspersed with melodious tones
Great-Grey Shrike: Largest of the shrikes, with a broad black mask and pale gray body
Hunts from high perches, diving down to catch prey
Utilizes a 'larder' to store food, impaling it on spikes
Inhabits open woodland, farmland, and scrub across Europe and Asia
Dominant and territorial, often seen alone or in pairs
Baird Sparrow: Small, cryptically colored sparrow with a rich, melodious song
Rufous cap and streaked back help it blend into its surroundings
Feeds mostly on seeds but includes insects during summer
Rare and elusive, known for its sudden, brief skylarking flights
Black-throated Sparrow: Distinguished by its black throat and white face, contrasting with gray upperparts
Desert specialist, adapted to arid Southwest landscapes
Diet includes seeds and insects, can survive long periods without water
Nests are built close to the ground in shrubs or cacti
Song is a clear, sweet series of whistles
Brewer Sparrow: Small size with a muted brown plumage
Noticeable streaks across a lighter breast
Distinctly marked brown cap atop its head
Tail longer in proportion to its body size
Pale yellow lower mandible on its bill
Chipping Sparrow: Compact bird with variable plumage coloration
White underparts distinguished by crisp black streaks
Sleek silhouette with a proportionately long black tail
Characteristic small and sharp black bill
Clay-colored Sparrow: Light brown overall plumage with darker, crisp streaks
Bright, white underparts accented with subtle streaking
Prominent dark line extending through the eye
Thin, slightly curved bill enhancing its delicate profile
Two noticeable white wing bars adding to its distinctive appearance
House Sparrow: Stout build with a mix of brown and black plumage
Iconic black bib and stripe adorning the male
Rounded bill, stout in appearance, colored in shades of grey to black
Short and square tail lending to a chunkier silhouette
Paler underparts contrasted with darker, browner upperparts
Field Sparrow: Rufous-toned back with clear, white underparts
Small, pinkish bill distinguishing it from others
Longer tail, often edged with white
White eye-ring giving it a gentle expression
Clear, white bars on wings against a mostly brown plumage
Fox Sparrow: Heavier set with rich rufous plumage
Vibrant contrast between its dark head and white throat
Streaked back and tail indicative of its dense habitat preference
Hefty, dark bill designed for foraging in thick underbrush
Prominent white eyebrow stripe offering a striking look
Grasshopper Sparrow: Subdued, earthy brown colors blending with grasslands
Fine, dark streaks across a lighter breast resembling grass shadows
Minimalist, clean head pattern with a central crown stripe
Short, conical bill for seed consumption
Pale brown legs, well-adapted to its terrestrial lifestyle
Harris Sparrow: Chunky build with a black bib and crown
Bold, pinkish bill setting it apart visually
White cheeks creating a striking contrast with the black head
Warm brown wings with darker streaks
Dark eyes set against a lighter face, enhancing its distinct look
Henslow Sparrow: Bright yellow face accents with an olive cap
Short, chunky bill, ideal for seed foraging
Longer legs aiding in movement through dense grass
Tail relatively short, with fine, dark banding
Le-Conte Sparrow: Buff-orange facial pattern with a fine gray nape
A fine, pointed bill suited for seed extraction
Streaked back with a blend of brown and black feathers
Tail appears elongated, assisting in agile flight
Bright, yellow eyes giving it a vigilant appearance
Lincoln Sparrow: Fine, crisp streaking across a buffy breast
Grayish-brown cap contrasting with white edges
Moderately long tail with a rounded appearance
Thick, bushy supercilium over a dark eye line
Pink legs and feet, less conspicuous in the underbrush
Nelson-Sharp-tailed Sparrow: Distinctive orange face with gray cheeks
Rufous wings accented with white streaks
Sharp, pointed tail aiding in its nimble flight
Black bill sharply contrasting with lighter plumage
Stout body making it look robust relative to its size
Savannah Sparrow: Yellowish lores distinguishing it from similar species
Fine, dark streaks across a pale underbelly
Short, notched tail providing balance during flight
Small, pinkish bill for picking seeds and insects
Streaked back with brown and black marking
Seaside Sparrow: Dark, streaked upperparts mimicking marsh reeds
Broad, whitish supercilium over a darker ear coverts
Robust body adapted to a life in dense marshes
Dark, short bill suited to its omnivorous diet
Tail short and notched, aiding in quick maneuvers
Song Sparrow: Richly streaked underparts with a central breast spot
Round, compact body fluffed in colder temperatures
Long, rounded tail often cocked upright
Broad, grayish bill blending with its mottled throat
Dark, brown eyes intensifying its inquisitive look
Tree Sparrow: Bright chestnut crown contrasting with its gray face
Wing bars appearing more buff than pure white
Rufous, narrow streaks along its flanks and back
Dark legs and feet, adept for perching in varied foliage
Vesper Sparrow: Pink legs and feet, contrasting with its paler belly
Distinctive white outer tail feathers flashing in flight
Crisp, chestnut shoulder patch visible in flight
Grayish head with fine streaks, blending into its habitat
White-crowned Sparrow: Bold, black-and-white head stripes as a distinguishing feature
Pale, gray breast lacking streaks, providing uniformity
Pink or yellowish bill, varying with age and region
Long, squared tail contributing to elegant proportions
Heavily streaked back with brown and gray tones
White-throated Sparrow: White throat sharply contrasting with its darker head
Bold yellow lores setting off a distinctive face pattern
Bill grayish, stout, and well-suited to seed foraging
Double white wing bars accenting dark wings
Hefty body form giving a plump appearance
Cape-Glossy Starling: Vibrant iridescent plumage reflecting blues and greens
Distinctive glossy sheen noticeable in sunlight
Bright yellow eyes stand out against dark plumage
Sharp, orange-yellow beak contrasts with glossy feathers
Sleek body shape with a notably long and pointed tail
Bank Swallow: Small size with a streamlined, agile body
Underparts range from white to pale, contrasting with darker upperparts
Noticeable dark band across the chest
Short, forked tail designed for quick aerial maneuvers
Brownish upperparts with slight gloss under sunlight
Barn Swallow: Deep, iridescent blue upperparts and a rufous to tawny underparts
Long, deeply forked tail with white spots on tail feathers
Aerial acrobat with sleek, pointed wings for swift flight
Distinctive reddish throat and forehead in adults
Juveniles show paler underparts and less forked tails
Cliff Swallow: Square-tailed with a buffy rump and white forehead patch
Dark, glossy blue-black upperparts with a contrasting pale underparts
Mud-built, gourd-shaped nests on vertical surfaces
Short, broad wings for maneuvering around cliff faces
Tree Swallow: Brilliant metallic blue-green upperparts and white underparts
Sleek, streamlined body with long, pointed wings
Frequently seen flying over water, catching insects mid-air
Social species, often nesting in large colonies
Juveniles have duller coloration and may appear brownish
Scarlet Tanager: Vivid scarlet body with contrasting black wings and tail
Females and non-breeding males are olive-yellow with darker wings
Prefers dense deciduous forests as habitats
Distinctive, rich song often heard before the bird is seen
Feeds on insects and fruit, often foraging high in the canopy
Summer Tanager: Entirely rose-red male with a slightly paler bill
Females are mustard-yellow, with some greenish shades on the back
Inhabits open woodlands and edges, often seen alone
Feeds primarily on bees and wasps, catching them in mid-flight
Nests are cup-shaped, placed on horizontal tree branches
Artic Tern: Famous for its long migratory journey, pole to pole
Bright red bill and legs contrast with its pale body
Deeply forked tail and slender wings for long-distance flight
Breeds in colonies on coasts and islands, often very aggressive in defense
Plumage transitions from a black cap in breeding season to a more mottled head in winter
Black Tern: Dark, sooty gray body with a lighter gray belly in breeding plumage
Non-breeding adults have a white head and underparts with dark wings
Elegant flight over water bodies, dipping down to catch prey
Nests in freshwater marshes, often forming loose colonies
Juveniles have a barred appearance with a dark bill and legs
Caspian Tern: Largest tern with a heavy red bill and a deep, raucous call
Breeding adults have a full black cap, transitioning to a patchy crown in non-breeding season
Prefers large bodies of water, from saltwater bays to inland lakes
Diet consists mainly of fish, caught with spectacular plunge-dives
Nests are simple scrapes on the ground, often on isolated beaches
Common Tern: Medium-sized tern with a slender body and pointed wings
Silver-gray plumage with a black cap and a red bill with a dark tip
Breeds in colonies on coasts, islands, and inland lakes
Flight is buoyant and graceful, often hovering before diving for fish
Winter plumage shows a white forehead and a less distinct cap
Elegant Tern: Long, slender bill with a slight droop, bright orange in color
Breeding plumage shows a shaggy crest and a clean white body
Nests in dense colonies on sandy beaches or islands
Highly social, often found in large flocks during migration
Feeds primarily on small fish, captured with precise aerial dives
Forsters Tern: Distinctive black eye patch in breeding plumage with a white body
In winter, the black cap is replaced by a white crown with a black spot near the eye
Favors marshes and coastal wetlands for breeding
Flight is light and buoyant; often hovers before diving for fish
Nests are floating platforms built from vegetation
Least Tern: Smallest of American terns with a yellow bill and a black tip
Sharp, rapid flight over shallow waters, catching small fish and crustaceans
Breeds on sandy beaches, often very close to the water's edge
Nests are simple scrapes in the sand, sometimes lined with shells or debris
Protective of nesting sites, may dive at intruders including humans
Green-tailed Towhee: Olive-green upperparts and bright rufous tail feathers
Distinctive white throat bordered by dark streaks
Prefers brushy habitats and chaparral for foraging and nesting
Scratches at the ground with both feet to uncover food
Song is a sweet, descending trill, often heard at dawn
Brown Thrasher: Rich brown upperparts with complex streaking on a white breast and belly
Long rufous tail and curved bill for probing into leaf litter
Dense shrubbery and thickets are preferred habitats
Vocal mimic with an extensive repertoire of songs and calls
Feeds on insects, fruits, and seeds, often seen foraging on the ground
Sage Thrasher: Smallest of the thrashers with a short, straight bill
Gray-brown plumage with white underparts heavily streaked with black
Inhabits sagebrush flats, where it is often more heard than seen
Song is a long, melodious series of warbles and trills
Nests are well-hidden in dense sagebrush or low shrubs

Vibrant olive-green upperparts contrast with pure white underparts

Black bill finely tuned for insect foraging

Blue-headed Vireo: Compact songbird sporting a striking blue-grey head

Dark legs, adept at navigating through foliage
Philadelphia Vireo: Small, agile bird with a greenish-olive to yellowish gradient plumage

Black bill, small yet effective for its dietary needs
Two white wing bars, adding to its delicate appearance

Forked tail, aiding in its acrobatic flights
